replies.bodyText: Indeed it is from @geofjamg I just have moved some code.
replies.author: annetill

timeline.bodyText:
There is something strange in the design: it's not related to your PR, but why the adder take one Extendable instance and the createExtension could take another one?
@MioRtia : what do you think?
timeline.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText: Hm, good question. In the code, createExtension is only called with the extendable field (from the constructor) as parameter. Maybe the method should not take any parameter and extendable should be protected? (@jonenst do you remember why you designed it this way?)
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: I did it this way because it was more explicit for an implementer of an adder to take the extendable as a method argument from the method he is supposed to implement. The alternative (that you mentionned) is to have the extendable in a protected field of the base class and document that it should be used in the createExtension method
replies.author: jonenst

replies.bodyText: I'm ok with both implementations if you want to change it
replies.author: jonenst

replies.bodyText: I guess it's not so implicit with a protected field because you have to write the constructor calling super() with the extendable so you are hinted about it
replies.author: jonenst

replies.bodyText: Ok, thank you for the explanation! Both are okay for me, what do you think @mathbagu ? In any case, I think this PR is good to be merged, we can make another PR on this subject later.
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText: The only thing I want we ensure, is that should be forbidden to pass a different instance. I think it could be the case with the abstract class we provide. It's not directly related to this PR, so I will merge it but the discussion is still open
replies.author: mathbagu

timeline.bodyText: Is there any restriction for this value? Do we have to implement a checkSlope method to ensure this value is in range, and use it in the constructor and the setter?
timeline.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText: Yes Indeed it should be positive in the load sign convention.
replies.author: annetill

timeline.bodyText: @mathbagu Help, it is not working and I think it is just because I am not familiar with xml conversion. Thanks !
timeline.author: annetill

replies.bodyText:
The error I get is:
com.powsybl.commons.exceptions.UncheckedSaxException: org.xml.sax.SAXParseException; lineNumber: 24; columnNumber: 60; cvc-complex-type.2.4.c : Le caractère générique concordant est strict, mais aucune déclaration ne peut être trouvée pour l'élément 'vprpc:voltagePerReactivePowerControl'.
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText:
The problem was that namespace was different in xsd and in the XML serializer class.
I removed the FIXME annotation.
I also fixed the expected value in the final assert (should be 0.5, that is the value used when creating the extension).
replies.author: zamarrenolm

replies.bodyText: Thanks a lot @zamarrenolm ! Have you check the cgmes conversion by the way ?
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: Yes, I saw that you are storing in the extension the slope attribute read in the staticVarCompensators SPARQL query, so for me it is ok.
replies.author: zamarrenolm

timeline.message:
fix namespace; fix expected value

Signed-off-by: Luma <zamarrenolm@aia.es>

timeline.author: mathbagu

timeline.bodyText:
Is it OK or should we throw an exception? If we accept negative value, it will never be possible to change that. It's better to throw an exception, and then make the code more permissive.
Moreover, in CGMES conversion, we do not create the extension if the slope is negative (or equal to 0)
timeline.author: mathbagu
